that the applicant may appeal to the court against the imposition of the condition, and
the period within which the appeal may be made.
If a registered certifier refuses to issue a strata certificate, the notice must state the grounds of refusal.

heading.b: Appeal to Land and Environment Court

block.txt: The applicant for an application for a strata certificate made to a local council may appeal to the court against a decision of the council—
to refuse the application, or
to issue the strata certificate subject to a restrictive use condition.
For the purposes of an appeal under this section, a local council is taken to have refused an application if the council does not decide the application within 14 days after—

if the application is for a strata certificate referred to in section 54 (1) and, in relation to the application, the council has given notice under that section to an owners corporation—the end of the period specified in the notice within which the owners corporation may give its views on the proposed subdivision to which the certificate relates, or
otherwise—the day the council receives the application.
An appeal must be made within 12 months after—
the day the applicant receives notice of the decision, or
if the local council is taken to have refused the application—the day the council is taken to have refused it.
However, the court may, if it considers it appropriate in the circumstances, extend the period for making the appeal.
A decision of the court on an appeal is taken to be the final decision of the local council and is to be given effect as if it were the decision of the council.

heading.b: Satisfaction about compliance with conditions precedent to issue of strata certificates

block.txt: A person who exercises functions under this Act or another Act in reliance on a strata certificate—
is entitled to assume that—
the certificate was properly issued, and
all conditions precedent to the issue of the certificate have been complied with, and
all things that are stated in the certificate as existing or having been done do exist or have been done, and
is not liable for any loss or damage arising from a matter in relation to which the certificate was issued.
This section does not apply to a registered certifier in relation to a strata certificate issued by the registered certifier.
The regulations may make provision for or with respect to the following matters—
applications for and the issue of strata certificates,
the matters to be notified by registered certifiers to local councils in relation to strata certificates,
the inspections to be carried out by local councils and registered certifiers in relation to the issue of strata certificates,
the records to be kept by local councils and registered certifiers in relation to strata certificates issued, or refused, by local councils and registered certifiers.
The purpose of this Part is to facilitate the development in stages of a parcel subject to a strata scheme.
This Part does not prevent the development of a parcel otherwise than in accordance with the Part.
In this Part—

court
means the Land and Environment Court.

development concern
—see section 74.

permitted development
—see section 73 (4).

warranted development
—see section 73 (3) (a).
The proposed development in stages of a parcel subject to a strata scheme consists of—
the progressive improvement of the parcel by the construction of buildings or the carrying out of works on development lots, and
the subsequent subdivision of each development lot and the consequential adjustment of the unit entitlement of lots in the scheme.

A development lot may be situated wholly or partly above, below or alongside the building to which the strata scheme initially relates, but must be identified as a development lot in the strata plan for the scheme when the plan is registered or in a strata plan of subdivision of a development lot.
The development is carried out subject to a strata development contract that describes separately—

Warranted development and authorised proposals are referred to as
permitted development
because the owners corporation of the strata scheme and other persons having estates or interests in lots included in the parcel must allow it to be carried out in accordance with the strata development contract.

A
development concern
, in relation to a strata development contract, is—
doing any of the following in accordance with the contract—
erecting structures, carrying out works or effecting other improvements,
creating easements, dedicating land, making by-laws or entering into covenants or management or other agreements,
creating or using common property,
adding land to the parcel,
using water, sewerage, drainage, gas, electricity, oil, garbage, conditioned air, telephone or other services available to the parcel, or installing additional services,
providing and using means of access or egress to or from a development lot, or to or from common property,
subdivision of a development lot, or excising a development lot from the parcel, and
carrying out any other development that is permitted to be carried out because it is included in the contract.

However, a
development concern
does not include—
subdivision of common property, or
amendment of a strata development contract, regardless of whether the subject-matter involved is, or relates to, a development concern.
A planning authority must not grant planning approval for the subdivision of land by a strata plan for the purposes of the development in stages of a parcel under this Part unless—
the proposed strata plan includes a development lot, and
the application for the planning approval is accompanied by a proposed strata development contract.
When a planning authority grants a planning approval in accordance with this section, it must certify in the approved form that carrying out the permitted development would not contravene—
any condition subject to which the approval was granted, or
the provisions of any environmental planning instrument in force when the approval was granted, except to the extent, if any, specified in the certificate.
A planning approval that purports to have been granted in contravention of this section is invalid.

heading.b: Strata development contracts and registration of contracts and amendments
Form and content of strata development contract

block.txt: A strata development contract must be in the approved form.
A strata development contract must include—
a concept plan that complies with section 77, and
a description of the following—
the land comprising the parcel, identifying separately the development lot or lots,
any land proposed to be added to the parcel at a later time,
any part of the common property in relation to which the developer is to have a right to occupy to carry out the proposed development,

any part of the proposed development that the developer is permitted by the contract to carry out and may be compelled to carry out (identified in the contract as “warranted development—proposed development subject to a warranty”),

any part of the proposed development that the developer is permitted by the contract to carry out but cannot, merely because it is described in the contract, be compelled to carry out (identified in the contract as “authorised proposals—proposed development not subject to a warranty”), and
any other information or document prescribed by the regulations.
A strata development contract must predict a time, not more than 10 years after the day on which the contract is registered, for the conclusion of the development scheme to which it relates.
A strata development contract that relates to development of a part strata parcel must include a description of the part of the building and its site outside the part strata parcel.
A strata development contract cannot provide for the subdivision of common property in a strata scheme without the consent, by special resolution, of the owners corporation.
A concept plan for a strata development contract must separately illustrate, in the way approved by the Registrar-General—
the sites proposed for, and the nature of, the buildings and works that would result from the carrying out of all permitted development under the contract, and
the sites proposed for, and the nature of, the buildings and works that would result from the carrying out of all warranted development.

heading.b: Variation of liability for common property expenses

block.txt: A strata development contract may apportion the liability for expenses relating to the use or maintenance of common property in the strata scheme differently from the way that liability would otherwise be apportioned by the schedule of unit entitlement for the scheme.

An apportionment under this section has effect despite the current schedule of unit entitlement, but does not apply to any liability that relates to the use or maintenance of the common property after the development scheme is concluded.

heading.b: Signing and lodging strata development contract and amendments

block.txt: The Registrar-General may register a strata development contract, or an amendment of a strata development contract, only if the contract or amendment is signed by all of the following—
the developer for the development lot,
each registered mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee and lessee of the development lot,
each registered mortgagee and chargee of a lease of the development lot,
if the contract or amendment relates to a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor of the scheme,
if the amendment is required, under section 84, to be supported by any resolution of the owners corporation of the strata scheme—the owners corporation.
A strata development contract, or an amendment of a strata development contract, must be lodged with the certificate required under section 75 (2) or 84 (7).

The Registrar-General may refuse to register a strata development contract or an amendment of a strata development contract if written consent to the registration has not been lodged and signed by any one or more of the following that the Registrar-General determines—
the judgment creditor under any writ recorded in the folio for the development lot,
the lessee of any common property in the strata scheme,
the caveator under a caveat affecting any estate or interest in the development lot.
The same person may be more than one of the parties to a strata development contract.

heading.b: Registering strata development contract and amendments

block.txt: The Registrar-General may register a strata development contract or an amendment of a strata development contract by recording the contract or amendment in the Register.

The Registrar-General may refuse to register an amendment of a strata development contract if the contract does not include a revised concept plan that will comply with section 77 after the amendment is registered.
The Registrar-General must refuse to register a strata development contract or an amendment of a strata development contract that does not comply with this Part.

A strata development contract has effect as an agreement under seal containing the covenants specified in Schedule 3 entered into by the owners corporation and each person who for the time being is any of the following—
the developer of the strata scheme,
if the scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor of the scheme,
an owner of a lot, other than the developer,
a registered mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee or lessee, or an occupier, of a lot.
The contract ceases to have effect—
in relation to a person described in subsection (1) (a), (b), (c) or (d), when the person ceases to be a person so described, and
in relation to all of the persons described in subsection (1), when the development scheme to which the contract relates is concluded.
Subsection (2) does not affect an obligation incurred by a person, or a right that accrued to a person, under the contract before it ceased to have effect in relation to the person.

A lessee entitled under a lease to immediate possession of a development lot is taken to be the developer, and the person who would otherwise be the developer is taken not to be the developer, for the purposes of this Act, the regulations and the strata development contract.

A mortgagee, chargee or covenant chargee in possession of a development lot is taken to be the developer, and the person who would otherwise be the developer is taken not to be the developer, for the purposes of this Act, the regulations and the strata development contract.
A strata development contract does not permit development to be carried out in contravention of this Act or any other Act or law.
A provision in any other contract or instrument under which a strata development contract is excluded, modified or restricted is void.
A covenant entered into under a strata development contract does not merge on the transfer of a lot.
This section does not affect a right or remedy a person may have apart from a right or remedy under a strata development contract.

However, the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
does not apply in relation to matters arising under a strata development contract.
A strata development contract for a strata scheme is void to the extent that it is inconsistent with a strata management statement for the scheme. See section 105 (7).

heading.b: Use of common property and development lot by developer

block.txt: A strata development contract may confer on a developer an exclusive, or any lesser, right to occupy common property specified in the contract.
When carrying out permitted development under a strata development contract, a developer is entitled to use common property or a development lot to which the contract relates—
to the extent necessary to carry out the development, or
to such other extent, if any, conferred by the contract in relation to specified common property.

A right conferred by this section may be exercised despite any other provision of this Act or any provision of the by-laws for the strata scheme or of an order under section 131 of the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
.
However, the right must be exercised in a way that does not cause unreasonable inconvenience to the occupier of any lot.

The provisions of a strata development contract that relate to the maintenance or upkeep of common property have effect despite any provision of the by-laws for the strata scheme or of an order under section 131 of the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
.

heading.b: Adding land to a parcel subject to a strata development contract

block.txt: Land may be added to a parcel containing a development lot by registration of a plan as a strata plan of subdivision.
The plan may be registered only if—
the land consisting of the former parcel and the additional land could be the subject of a strata plan had the land in the former parcel not already been subdivided under this Act, and
the strata development contract, as in force when the plan is registered—
provides for the land to be added to the parcel, and

states whether, on it being added to the parcel, the land will become common property, a further development lot or an addition to an existing development lot, or any specified combination of them, and

a plan showing as a single lot the additional land and the former parcel has been lodged for registration under the
Conveyancing Act 1919
.

On registration of the plan as a strata plan of subdivision, the land becomes common property, a further development lot or an addition to an existing development lot, or any specified combination of them, as provided by the strata development contract.
A strata development contract for a strata scheme may be amended by the developer.
An amendment must be in the approved form and has effect only if it—
is made in compliance with this Division, and
is registered, and
is not inconsistent with a registered strata management statement for the strata scheme.
A proposed amendment that involves a change in the basic architectural or landscaping design of the development, or in its essence or theme, may be made only if it is—
approved by the planning authority, and
supported by a unanimous resolution of the owners corporation of the strata scheme, unless the developer is the only owner of lots in the scheme.

An amendment proposed to give effect to a change in the law or a change in the requirements of a planning authority, and that does not involve a change referred to in subsection (3), may be made only if—
it is approved by the planning authority, and
notice of the amendment is given to—
the owners corporation of the strata scheme, and
the owner of each lot in the scheme, other than the developer, and
each registered mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee and lessee of a lot in the scheme.
Any other proposed amendment that would require a change in the terms of a planning approval may be made only if it is—
approved by the planning authority, and
supported by a special resolution of the owners corporation of the strata scheme.
Any other proposed amendment that would not require a change in the terms of a planning approval may be made only if—
it is supported by a resolution of the owners corporation of the strata scheme, and

the application for registration, or the contract as intended to be amended, is accompanied by a certificate, given in the approved form by the planning authority to the effect that a change in the terms of any planning approval is not required.

A planning authority that approves an amendment of a strata development contract must give the applicant for the approval a copy of the instruments, plans and drawings that describe and illustrate the amendment and a certificate in the approved form to the effect that—
the copy describes and illustrates the approved amendment, and
the contract, if amended as approved, would not be inconsistent with any related planning approval.
An amendment is not required to be supported by a resolution of the owners corporation if the amendment is approved by the court under section 86.

heading.b: Notice of particular decision, and appeal

block.txt: If a planning authority does not approve an amendment of a strata development contract, the authority must give the applicant for the approval a notice stating—
the grounds for the refusal, and
that the applicant may appeal to the court against the refusal, and
the period within which the appeal may be made.
The applicant may appeal to the court against the refusal within 12 months after receiving the notice.
However, the court may, if it considers it appropriate in the circumstances, extend the period for making the appeal.
A decision of the court on appeal is taken to be the final decision of the planning authority and is to be given effect as if it were the decision of the planning authority.

heading.b: Approval of amendments by Land and Environment Court

block.txt: Despite section 84, an amendment of a strata development contract is not required to be supported by a resolution of an owners corporation if the amendment is approved by the court.
The court may approve an amendment only if it is satisfied—
that a motion supporting the amendment has been defeated, or
that the notice of intention to move a motion supporting the amendment has been given but a meeting to consider the motion has not been held within a reasonable time after the notice was given, or
that the consent to the amendment of a mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee or lessee has been sought but has been refused.
The developer must serve an application for the court’s approval on all of the following—
each owner of a lot in the strata scheme, other than the developer,
each person, other than the applicant, who is the owner of a development lot,
each registered mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee and lessee of a lot in the scheme,
if the strata scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor (unless the lessor is the developer),
the owners corporation,
the planning authority.
Each person entitled to be served with the application is entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.

The vote of a developer who is permitted to carry out development because it is included in a strata development contract is sufficient to pass or defeat a motion included in the notice for a meeting of the owners corporation or its strata committee if the passing or defeat of the motion would have the effect of making a decision about a development concern.

A decision about a development concern need not be supported by a special or unanimous resolution of an owners corporation, despite any other provision of this Act or the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
.

A dealing, plan or other instrument may be executed by the owners corporation or by a developer on behalf of the owners corporation for the purpose of giving effect to a decision about a development concern.

The regulations may impose requirements for the execution of dealings, plans and other instruments by owners corporations and developers and may require verification by statutory declaration of the circumstances in which they were executed.

heading.b: Meetings of owners corporation relating to development concerns

block.txt: A motion, the passing or defeat of which at a meeting of the owners corporation or its strata committee would have the effect of making a decision about a development concern, must be—
identified as relating to a development concern in the notice for the meeting, and
moved separately from any other kind of motion.

A general meeting of the owners corporation for the purpose of making a decision about a development concern may be convened under Schedule 1 to the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
by the developer or the owners of at least 25% of the lots in the strata scheme that are not development lots.
In convening the general meeting, the developer or any of the owners convening the meeting may give notice of the meeting on behalf of the strata committee of the owners corporation.

The presence of the developer (or if the developer is a corporation, of the company nominee of the corporation) constitutes a sufficient quorum for any meeting of the owners corporation or its strata committee of which notice has been properly given.
Subsection (4) applies only while business relating to a development concern is being dealt with.

For the purpose only of allowing development permitted by a strata development contract to be carried out, a developer (or if the developer is a corporation, the company nominee of the corporation) may exercise the functions of an owners corporation bound by the contract, or of another person having functions under the strata scheme, that are prescribed by the regulations.

This section has effect despite any other provision of this Act or the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
.
A development scheme to which a strata development contract relates is concluded when any of the following happens—
any planning approval required for carrying out the scheme is revoked,

a strata plan of subdivision that subdivides the last remaining unsubdivided development lot to which the contract relates, or subdivides the residue of that development lot after excision of part of the lot in accordance with the contract, is registered,
the conclusion time for the development scheme arrives,
a notice in the approved form, that complies with subsection (2) and stating that the development scheme to which the contract relates has concluded, is registered,
the strata scheme to which the contract relates is terminated under Part 9 by an order of the Supreme Court.
For the purpose of subsection (1) (d), the notice must—
be signed by the developer, and
be signed by each registered mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee and lessee of the development lot, and

be lodged with a certificate, given in the approved form by the owners corporation of the strata scheme, certifying that the owners corporation has, by unanimous resolution, agreed that the development scheme has concluded.
In this section—

conclusion time
for a development scheme means—
the time predicted by the contract for conclusion of the development scheme, or
if the time referred to in paragraph (a) is changed by an order under section 92—the time provided for under the order.

If, at the conclusion of a development scheme, the owners corporation considers that the schedule of unit entitlement for the strata scheme does not apportion the unit entitlements so as to reflect the market value of the lots in the strata scheme, the owners corporation may lodge a revised schedule of unit entitlement for the scheme.
The revised schedule of unit entitlement must be lodged within 2 years after the conclusion of the development scheme.
A revised schedule of unit entitlement must—
be in the approved form, and
be clearly identified as a revised schedule of unit entitlement, and
show, as a whole number apportioned on a market value basis and totalling the unit entitlements, the unit entitlement of each lot, and
be accompanied by a certificate in the approved form signed by a qualified valuer certifying that the unit entitlements of the lots are apportioned on a market value basis, and

be accompanied by a certificate in the approved form signed by the owners corporation and certifying that it has, by special resolution, agreed to the substitution of the existing schedule of unit entitlement with the revised schedule.
In this section—

market value basis
—see clause 1 of Schedule 2.

heading.b: Registrar-General to record matters about conclusion of development scheme

block.txt: The Registrar-General must record the conclusion of a development scheme in the folio for the owners corporation and the common property in the strata scheme.

If, after the conclusion of a development scheme, a revised schedule of unit entitlement for the scheme is lodged under section 90, the Registrar-General must record it as the schedule of unit entitlement in substitution for the existing schedule of unit entitlement for the scheme.

heading.b: Order for extension or conclusion of development scheme

block.txt: On application made to it by any person bound by a strata development contract, the court may, by order, do either or both of the following—
defer, either generally or to a specified time, the time at which a development scheme would otherwise be concluded,
fix a time for the conclusion of a development scheme, whether it is an earlier or a later time than it would otherwise be.
The applicant for the order must serve notice of the application, in accordance with rules of court, on all of the following—
the developer,
each owner of a lot in the strata scheme, other than the developer,
each registered mortgagee, chargee, covenant chargee and lessee of a lot in the scheme,
if the strata scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor (unless the lessor is the developer),
the owners corporation,
the planning authority,
the Registrar-General,
any other person directed by the court.
Each person entitled to be served with notice of the application may appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.
An order under this section may—
contain provisions relating to the strata scheme that the court considers necessary because of the conclusion of the development scheme, and

require the payment of an amount to or by the owners corporation or the owners of lots to any one or more of them in addition to, or instead of, an award of damages in the exercise of the jurisdiction conferred by section 20 (2) (d) of the
Land and Environment Court Act 1979
, and
contain other provisions and requirements the court considers just and equitable.

The court may, from time to time, vary an order under this section on the application of any person entitled to apply for an order. This section applies to an application for a variation of an order in the same way as it applies to an application for an order.
An owners corporation or an owner of a lot, other than the developer, may apply in writing to the Secretary for assistance to bring or defend proceedings before the court relating to—
a strata development contract or an amendment of any such contract, or
an agreement implied by section 81, or
a planning approval granted in accordance with section 75 (1) or a modification of any such approval.
After receiving an application, the Secretary—
may require the applicant to give the Secretary further information about the application that the Secretary considers may assist investigation of the application, and
may refuse to proceed with the application until the further information is given.

For the purpose of this Division, an application under subsection (1) is called an
application for assistance
.
The Secretary may decide to proceed with an investigation of an application for assistance or, having proceeded with an investigation, decide to discontinue the investigation.
In making the decision, the Secretary must have regard to whether, in the opinion of the Secretary—
the application is frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance, or
the applicant has unreasonably delayed complying with a requirement for further information, or
investigation, or further investigation, is a matter for a planning authority, or
the applicant has an alternative and better means of redress.
The Secretary may have regard to other matters the Secretary considers appropriate.
If the Secretary decides to investigate an application, the Secretary must—
inform the applicant of the decision, and
inform the owners corporation of the decision and the subject-matter of the investigation, unless the owners corporation is the applicant, and
inform the developer and the relevant planning authority of the decision and the subject-matter of the investigation, and
invite each person referred to in paragraph (b) or (c), other than the applicant, to give the Secretary a written submission about the subject-matter within a specified period.
If the Secretary decides not to investigate an application or to discontinue an investigation, the Secretary must—
inform the applicant of the decision, and
if the decision is to discontinue an investigation—inform each other person the Secretary informed of the original decision to investigate the application.

heading.b:
Application of
Fair Trading Act 1987
to investigation

block.txt:
Sections 20–22 of the
Fair Trading Act 1987
apply to an investigation of an application for assistance as if—
references in the sections to information, documents or evidence included references to information, documents or evidence relating to an application for assistance, and

references in the sections to an investigator included references to the Secretary and to any person who has been delegated the powers conferred on the Secretary in relation to an application for assistance, and
references in the sections to that Act included references to this Act.

Sections 20–22 of the
Fair Trading Act 1987
provide for matters about obtaining information, documents or evidence in relation to an investigation, the inspection and copying of documents and the confidentiality of information, documents and evidence obtained.

Division 2, other than sections 12 and 15 (6), of Part 2 of the
Fair Trading Act 1987
, applies to an application for assistance in the same way as it applies to an application under section 12 of that Act.

The Secretary may, with the consent of the Minister administering the
Fair Trading Act 1987
, seek an interim restraining order under section 124 of the
Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979
in relation to the subject-matter of the application.
The Secretary may seek the order whether or not investigation of the application has been completed.
The order may be granted without any undertaking being given by the Secretary as to damages.

An interim restraining order sought by the Secretary is, for the purposes of subsection (1), taken to have been sought by the person who made the application for assistance and that person is taken to be an assisted person under Division 2 of Part 2 of the
Fair Trading Act 1987
.

heading.b: Resolution authorising application by owners corporation

block.txt: An owners corporation may, if authorised by resolution—
make an application for assistance, or

bring proceedings referred to in section 123 of the
Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979
or section 20 (1) (e) of the
Land and Environment Court Act 1979
relating to—
a strata development contract or an amendment of any such contract, or
a planning approval granted in accordance with section 75 (1) of this Act or a modification of any such approval.

Any vote cast by the developer (whether as an owner of a lot or as a mortgagee, covenant chargee or proxy) or by a mortgagee of the developer (whether as a mortgagee, covenant chargee or proxy) is to be disregarded in determining whether a resolution has been passed.
The Secretary may—
give advice about the remedies available in relation to matters arising under this Part, and
try to bring the interested parties to an agreement that will settle any question, dispute or difficulty that arises from the operation of this Part, and
advise the relevant planning authority of any departure from the terms of a planning approval or strata development contract.

heading.b: Strata management statements and easements relating to part strata parcels
Requirement to register strata management statement

block.txt: The Registrar-General must not register a plan as a strata plan that creates a part strata parcel unless the Registrar-General also registers a strata management statement for the building and its site or waives, under subsection (2), the requirement for a strata management statement.
The Registrar-General may waive the requirement for a strata management statement—
if—
the building is erected on a lot in a community scheme, and
only part of the building and site is to be subdivided by a strata plan, and

all of the residue of the building and site is to be community property within the meaning of the
Community Land Management Act 2021
, or
if—
the plan relates to part of a building that includes one or more part strata parcels, and
a strata management statement has already been registered for the building and its site, or
if a registered building management statement is in force for the building and its site, or
if the Minister, on the grounds the Minister considers sufficient, directs.

heading.b: Form and content of strata management statement

block.txt: A strata management statement must be in the approved form and comply with Schedule 4, and that Schedule applies to the statement.

heading.b: Registration of strata management statement and amendment

block.txt: The Registrar-General may register a strata management statement or an amendment of a strata management statement by recording the statement or amendment in the Register.

The Registrar-General may refuse to register a strata management statement or an amendment of a strata management statement if the application for registration does not comply with a requirement of this Act or the regulations.

The Registrar-General may register a strata management statement for a building and its site at any time part of the building is included in a part strata parcel but is not the subject of a strata management statement.

heading.b: Recording information about strata management statement in folios

block.txt: If a strata management statement is registered, the Registrar-General must record the following in the relevant folios—
the existence of the statement and of each registered amendment of it,
other information relating to the statement and each amendment that the Registrar-General considers appropriate.
In this section—

relevant folios
means the folios for—
each owners corporation of a strata scheme for part of the building, and
each part of the building or site that does not form part of a part strata parcel.
A registered strata management statement may be amended only if the amendment is—
supported by the following—
a special resolution of the owners corporation of each strata scheme for part of the building,
each person in whom is vested an estate in fee simple in a part of the building or its site that is not included in a part strata parcel,

if the building is the subject of a leasehold strata scheme—each person in whom is vested a leasehold estate, recorded in a folio, in a part of the building or its site that is not included in a part strata parcel, or
ordered under this Act or another Act by a court, or

consequential on the revocation or modification, under section 103 of the
Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979
, of a planning approval.
An amendment of a strata management statement must be in the approved form and has effect under this Part only if it is recorded in the folio for—
each owners corporation of a strata scheme for part of the building, and
each part of the building or site that does not form part of a part strata parcel.

heading.b: Signing of strata management statement and amendment

block.txt: The Registrar-General may register a strata management statement or an amendment of a strata management statement only if the statement or amendment is—

signed by the owners corporation of each strata scheme, if any, for a part of the building and is accompanied by evidence to show that it is supported by a special resolution of the owners corporation, and
signed by each person in whom is vested an estate in fee simple in a part of the building or its site that is not included in a part strata parcel, and

if the building is the subject of a leasehold strata scheme—signed by each person in whom is vested a leasehold estate in a part of the building or its site that is not included in a part strata parcel, and
signed by each registered mortgagee, chargee or covenant chargee of an estate referred to in paragraph (b) or (c).

The Registrar-General may refuse to register a strata management statement or an amendment of a strata management statement unless written consent to the registration has been lodged and signed by one or more of the following as the Registrar-General determines—

the lessee under any lease, or the judgment creditor under any writ, recorded in a folio for an estate referred to in subsection (1) (b) or (c) or the folio relating to any common property affected by the statement or amendment,
the caveator under a caveat affecting any estate or interest referred to in subsection (1) (b), (c) or (d).
The Registrar-General may, in a particular case, waive a requirement for a signature under this section without giving notice to any person.

A registered strata management statement for a building has effect as an agreement under seal containing the covenants referred to in subsection (2) entered into by each person who for the time being is—
the owners corporation of a strata scheme for part of the building, or
an owner, mortgagee in possession or lessee of a lot in a strata scheme for part of the building, or
another person in whom is vested the fee simple of a part of the building or site affected by the statement, or
the mortgagee in possession or lessee of a part of the building or site referred to in paragraph (c).
The covenants referred to in subsection (1) are—
a covenant by which the persons jointly and severally agree to carry out their obligations under the registered strata management statement, and
a covenant by which the persons jointly and severally agree to permit the carrying out of the obligations.
The agreement ceases to have effect under this Part—
in relation to a person referred to in subsection (1) (b), (c) or (d), on the person ceasing to be that person, and
in relation to all persons referred to in subsection (1), on the termination of all strata schemes to which the strata management statement relates.
Subsection (3) does not prejudice or affect an obligation incurred by, or a right that accrued to, a person under the agreement while it was in force.
A strata management statement has no effect to the extent that it is inconsistent with—
a condition imposed on a planning approval relating to the site of the building to which the statement relates, or

an order under Part 12 of the
Strata Schemes Management Act 2015
, or
another Act or law.
Subject to this Act and the regulations, a provision in any instrument under which the agreement is excluded, modified or restricted is void.

Without limiting subsection (6), a provision of a strata development contract relating to a strata scheme is void to the extent that it is inconsistent with a provision of a strata management statement relating to the scheme.
A covenant entered into under the agreement does not merge in a transfer of a lot.
This section does not affect a right or remedy that a person may have under a strata management statement apart from a right or remedy under this Part.

heading.b: Easements on registration of strata plan that creates part strata parcel

block.txt: On registration of a plan as a strata plan that creates a part strata parcel, the following easements are implied in relation to the lots and common property comprising the part strata parcel and situated within a building—
an easement benefiting the lots and common property for their subjacent and lateral support and burdening other parts of the building capable of affording support,
an easement burdening the lots and common property for subjacent and lateral support and benefiting other parts of the building capable of enjoying support,
an easement benefiting the lots and common property for their shelter and burdening all other parts of the building capable of affording shelter,
an easement burdening the lots and common property for shelter and benefiting other parts of the building capable of being sheltered by the lots and common property.
All ancillary rights and obligations reasonably necessary to make easements effective apply in relation to the easements.
An easement for support or shelter—
entitles the owner of the dominant tenement to enter the servient tenement to replace, renew or restore the support or shelter, and
subsists until the easement is extinguished.
The Registrar-General must record the easements in the Register.

This section applies despite section 88 of the
Conveyancing Act 1919
.

heading.b: Other easements in particular strata schemes

block.txt: This section applies if an instrument lodged with a strata plan that creates a part strata parcel purports to create any of the following easements burdening or benefiting the part strata parcel or the land comprised in the part strata parcel—
a right of vehicular access,
a right of personal access,
an easement for a specified service.

The rights and obligations conferred or imposed by the easement are the rights and obligations specified in Schedule 5, other than to the extent the rights or obligations are varied or negatived under this section or in the instrument.

The terms of an easement referred to in subsection (1) may be varied under section 47 of the
Real Property Act 1900
, to the extent the terms relate to—
the responsibility for maintaining in good order or repairing the access or other things required for enjoyment of the easement, or
the proportions in which the persons having the benefit or burden of the easement are liable to contribute to the cost of maintaining in good order or repairing the access or other things.

On application by a person who has an estate or interest in land that has the benefit or burden of an easement to which this section applies, the Supreme Court may, by order, vary the terms of the easement to the extent the terms relate to a matter referred to in subsection (3) (a) or (b).
The Registrar-General must, on application made in the approved form, make all necessary recordings in the Register to give effect to an order.

On registration under subsection (5), an order is binding on all persons entitled or later becoming entitled to the easement, whether of full age or capacity or not and whether the persons are parties to the proceedings or have been served with notice or not.

Despite section 88 of the
Conveyancing Act 1919
, the site of an easement for a specified service need not be identified on the strata plan.
In this section—

drainage
includes the product of rain, a storm, soakage, a spring or seepage.

service
means a water, sewerage, drainage, gas, electricity, oil, garbage, conditioned air, telephone, television or radio impulses or signals service or another service prescribed by the regulations.

heading.b: Registered building management statement taken to be strata management statement

block.txt: This section applies if the Registrar-General—
registers a plan as a strata plan that creates a part strata parcel, and
under section 99 (2), waives the requirement for a strata management statement because a registered building management statement is in force for the building and its site.
On registration of the plan, the building management statement is taken to be the registered strata management statement for the building and its site.

heading.b: Obligation of lessee to comply with particular management statements

block.txt: In a lease of a lot or common property in a strata scheme that is part of a community scheme, an agreement by the lessee to comply with the following is implied—

if the strata scheme is also part of a precinct scheme under the
Community Land Development Act 2021
—the precinct management statement under that Act for the precinct scheme.

heading.b: Obligation to give information about particular management statements

block.txt: If it is proposed to grant a lease of a lot or common property in a strata scheme that is part of a community scheme, the lessor must include a copy of the following with the copy of the lease to be signed by the lessee—

if the strata scheme is also part of a precinct scheme under the
Community Land Development Act 2021
—the precinct management statement under that Act for the precinct scheme.
Maximum penalty—1 penalty unit.

heading.b: Compulsory acquisition of lots and common property

block.txt: This Part does not apply to—
an easement, or
land in a strata scheme that is part of a community scheme.
A resuming authority cannot resume land—
comprising solely common property, unless the resumed land is defined in the notice of resumption as a lot in a current plan, or
comprising or including all the lots in a strata scheme, unless—
the resumed land also includes all common property in the scheme and the notice of resumption states whether the resumed land is to be excluded from the strata scheme or to remain in the scheme, and
if any resumed land is to be excluded from the scheme—the resumed land is defined in the notice of resumption as a lot in a current plan, and

if any resumed land is a lot that is to remain in the scheme—the resumed land is defined in the notice of resumption as one or more lots in a strata plan, strata plan of subdivision or strata plan of consolidation, or
comprising some, but not all, of the lots in a strata scheme and any common property in the scheme, unless—
the notice of resumption states whether the resumed land is to be excluded from the strata scheme or to remain in the scheme, and
if any resumed land is to be excluded from the scheme—the resumed land is defined in the notice of resumption as a lot in a current plan, and

if any resumed land is a lot that is to remain in the scheme—the resumed land is defined in the notice of resumption as one or more lots in a strata plan, strata plan of subdivision or strata plan of consolidation.
This section applies despite any other Act.

heading.b: Requirements for registration of plans to effect resumption

block.txt: The Registrar-General must not register a plan that relates to a parcel and is lodged by a resuming authority to effect a resumption referred to in section 112 (1) unless—
the notice of resumption complies with that subsection, and
the plan includes a statement or otherwise indicates that registration of the plan is required to effect the resumption, and

if the plan is lodged for registration as a current plan that relates to all the lots and all the common property in a strata scheme—it is accompanied by a certified or office copy of the minute of an order made under section 136 in relation to the resumption, and

if the plan is lodged for registration as a current plan that does not relate solely to common property and is not a plan to which paragraph (c) applies—it is accompanied by a certified or office copy of the minute of an order made under section 115, 131 or 136, or an order dismissing the application for any such order, in relation to the resumption.

Despite section 22, a plan that is intended to effect a resumption and is lodged for registration as a strata plan of subdivision may be registered if it is signed or sealed by or on behalf of the resuming authority.

Despite section 195D (1) of the
Conveyancing Act 1919
, a plan that is intended to effect a resumption and is lodged for registration as a current plan may be registered if it is signed or sealed by or on behalf of the resuming authority.
If land was common property immediately before its resumption, the land ceases to be common property and this Act ceases to apply to the land on its resumption.
However, subsection (1) does not apply to a resumption of all lots and all common property in a strata scheme if the notice of resumption states the resumed land is to remain in the scheme.

If a notice of resumption states that any resumed lots in a strata scheme are to be excluded from the scheme, the lots cease to be subject to the strata scheme, and this Act ceases to apply to the lots, on the resumption.

If a notice of resumption states that any resumed land is to remain in the scheme, this Act applies in relation to the resuming authority and the resumed land as if the resuming authority had acquired the land by registration under the
Real Property Act 1900
of a transfer.
Subsection (4) applies despite any other Act.

heading.b: Readjustment of strata scheme for purposes of resumption

block.txt: A resuming authority may apply to the Supreme Court for an order under subsection (4) if the resuming authority—
proposes to resume land in a parcel and the land does not consist solely of common property or of all the lots and all the common property comprised in the parcel, and
proposes to exclude the land from the strata scheme.
Notice of the application must be served, in accordance with rules of court, on—
each owner and registered mortgagee of a lot in the strata scheme, and
if the strata scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor of the scheme, and
the owners corporation, and
if part of a lot is proposed to be resumed and the local council has not approved of a plan referred to in section 113 (1) (d) relating to the part—the local council, and
the Registrar-General, and
any other person directed by the Supreme Court.
A person who is entitled to be served with a notice under subsection (2) and the resuming authority are entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.
The Supreme Court may, on an application made under subsection (1), make an order for or in relation to any one or more of the following matters—
amending the existing schedule of unit entitlement or substituting a new schedule of unit entitlement for the existing schedule of unit entitlement,
if part of a lot is to be resumed and the resuming authority proposes to exclude the part from the strata scheme—designating as a lot the residue of the lot affected by the resumption,
amending a strata development contract that relates to the parcel,

requiring the resuming authority, when resuming the land referred to in its application, also to resume any residue referred to in paragraph (b) so that the residue will either be excluded from the strata scheme or remain subject to the scheme, according to the terms of the order,

with the consent of the owner of a lot part of which is proposed to be resumed—vesting, freed and discharged from any mortgage, charge, covenant charge or writ, any other part of the lot in the owners corporation as common property,
any matter in relation to which the Supreme Court considers it just and equitable, in the circumstances of the case, to make provision in the order.
An order made under subsection (4)—
takes effect on the day on which the resumption referred to in the order takes effect, and
has effect according to its tenor.
If, on an application made under subsection (1), the Supreme Court considers that an order should not be made under subsection (4)—

the court may, on application made by any person entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application or on its own initiative, direct that the application be treated as an application for an order under section 131 or 136, and
if the court makes a direction referred to in paragraph (a)—
the application the subject of the direction is taken to be an application made under section 130 or 135 by a person entitled to make the application, and
the applicant under subsection (1), and any other person entitled to appear and be heard under those sections, is entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.
The costs of proceedings for an application under section 115 are payable by the resuming authority unless the Supreme Court otherwise orders.

heading.b: Common property not to pass with lot or part of lot in certain circumstances

block.txt: A resuming authority does not acquire any interest in common property in a strata scheme merely because it resumes the whole or part of a lot that immediately before the resumption was a lot in the scheme if the notice of resumption states that the lot is to be excluded from the scheme.
For the purposes of any Act relating to the payment of compensation on the resumption of land—
a part of a lot that is resumed is taken to be severed from every other part of the lot, whether or not the part and any other part are contiguous, and

if the resumed land or any part of the resumed land is common property, the beneficial interests of the owners in the common property is taken to be vested in the owners corporation to the exclusion of the owners for the purposes of any claim for or the payment of compensation in relation to the resumption.

heading.b: Resumption by authority bound by Act

block.txt:
Despite section 8 of the
Land Acquisition (Just Terms Compensation) Act 1991
, a resumption of land to which this Part and that Act apply must comply with this Part and that Act.

A resumption of land to which this Part applies and to which Part 12 of the
Roads Act 1993
applies must comply with this Part and that Part.
If there is an inconsistency between this Part and an Act referred to in subsection (1) or (2), this Part prevails to the extent of the inconsistency.

heading.b: Resumption by authority not bound by Act

block.txt: If a part of a parcel is resumed by a resuming authority that is not bound by this Act and does not comply with this Part, the owners corporation or a person affected by the resumption may apply under Part 9 for an order under section 131 (Order to vary strata scheme), as if the building had been damaged or destroyed, or for an order under section 136 (Order to terminate strata scheme).

heading.b: Registration of plans and other instruments

block.txt: The Registrar-General may, subject to and for the purposes of this Act, register a plan or other instrument lodged for registration.

A plan is registered as a strata plan, strata plan of subdivision, strata plan of consolidation or building alteration plan when the Registrar-General records on the plan, in the Register or in another record kept by the Registrar-General, the matters about the plan the Registrar-General considers appropriate.
Subsection (2) is subject to sections 11 (2) and 16 (2).

Under sections 11 (2) and 16 (2), a plan that is lodged for registration as a strata plan or strata plan of subdivision for a leasehold strata scheme and is required to be accompanied by a lease or leases for registration under the
Real Property Act 1900
is taken to be registered only when the lease or leases are registered.
A notice is registered as a notice of conversion when the Registrar-General records the notice in the Register.

Despite any other provision of this Act, a plan or notice referred to in this section must not be registered unless all other plans or documents prescribed by the regulations are lodged with the plan or notice.

heading.b: Provisions applying to plans and certain other documents

block.txt: A certified copy has, for all purposes, the same validity and effect as the original document to which it relates.
If the Registrar-General certifies a document under subsection (1), the Registrar-General may destroy, or cease to keep in electronic form, the original document to which the certified copy relates.
In this section—

document
means—
a plan, strata development contract or strata management statement, or amendment of a strata development contract or strata management statement, that is registered, or
a copy of a document referred to in paragraph (a), or

a strata plan or strata plan of resubdivision within the meaning of the repealed
Conveyancing (Strata Titles) Act 1961
.

If a whole number is obtained by dividing by a whole number the unit entitlements of the lots and proposed lots shown on a proposed schedule of unit entitlement for a strata scheme that accompanies a plan lodged for registration, or on a revised schedule of unit entitlement lodged under section 90, the Registrar-General may, in registering the plan, record in the folio for the common property—
as the unit entitlement of each lot, the whole number obtained in relation to the lot, and
as the aggregate unit entitlement, the appropriate aggregate unit entitlement.

If a whole number is obtained by dividing by a whole number the unit entitlement of each lot in a strata scheme, the Registrar-General may amend the schedule of unit entitlement recorded in the folio for the common property—
by substituting for the unit entitlement of each lot a unit entitlement equal to the whole number obtained in relation to the lot, and
by substituting for the aggregate unit entitlement the appropriate aggregate unit entitlement.

The Registrar-General must, on making a recording or amendment under this section, give the owners corporation of the strata scheme written notice of the unit entitlements and aggregate unit entitlement recorded.

If a strata certificate issued by a local council is subject to a restrictive use condition, or a strata certificate issued by a registered certifier has a notation of a restrictive use condition, the Registrar-General must, on creating a folio for the lot, record the condition in the folio.

A condition recorded under subsection (1) is an interest for the purposes of section 42 of the
Real Property Act 1900
.
On lodgment of an instrument referred to in section 64, the Registrar-General must record the instrument in the Register.
When the Registrar-General makes the record, the utility lot to which the instrument relates is released from the restriction referred to in the instrument.

heading.b: Prohibition on recordings in the Register in certain circumstances

block.txt: This section applies if the Registrar-General registers a strata plan of subdivision or a current plan in relation to a resumption referred to in section 112 (1).

Until the Registrar-General makes a recording in the Register under section 31A (3) of the
Real Property Act 1900
in relation to the resumption, the Registrar-General must not—
create a folio for a lot comprised in the strata plan of subdivision or a current plan lot in the current plan, or
make a recording in the Register by reference to any such lot or current plan lot.

heading.b: Certain recordings to be made by Registrar-General

block.txt: If the Registrar-General registers a strata plan of subdivision that is not a plan referred to in section 125, or registers a strata plan of consolidation, the Registrar-General must—
cancel the folio for any former lot subdivided or consolidated by the registration of the plan, and
create a folio for each new lot created by the subdivision or consolidation, and
amend the schedule of unit entitlement recorded in the folio for the common property in the strata scheme by recording in the folio the matters the Registrar-General considers appropriate.
If the Registrar-General registers a notice of conversion of a lot into common property, the Registrar-General must—
cancel the folio for the converted lot, and
amend the schedule of unit entitlement recorded in the folio for the common property in the strata scheme by recording in the folio the matters the Registrar-General considers appropriate.

heading.b: Functions if resumed land remains in strata scheme

block.txt: Subsection (2) applies if the whole of a lot, other than a lot in a strata plan of subdivision referred to in section 125, is resumed and the notice of resumption states that the resumed land is to remain in the strata scheme.

A recording in the Register that the Registrar-General is, under section 31A (3) of the
Real Property Act 1900
, authorised or required to make in relation to the resumption must be made in the folio for the resumed lot.

Subsection (4) applies if the whole of a lot in a strata plan of subdivision referred to in section 125 is resumed and the notice of resumption states that the resumed land is to be excluded from the strata scheme.

The Registrar-General must, after making a recording in the Register under section 31A (3) of the
Real Property Act 1900
, in relation to the resumption—
cancel the folio for the subdivided lot, and
create a folio for each new lot, and
amend the schedule of unit entitlement recorded in the folio for the common property in the strata scheme by recording in the folio the matters the Registrar-General considers appropriate.

heading.b: Functions if resumed land is excluded from strata scheme

block.txt:
If land consisting solely of common property is resumed, any recording in the Register that, under section 31A (3) of the
Real Property Act 1900
, the Registrar-General is authorised or required to make must be made in the folio for the common property.
Subsection (3) applies if—
the whole of a parcel or any part of a parcel that does not consist of common property is resumed, and
the notice of resumption states that the resumed land is to be excluded from the strata scheme, and

the Registrar-General makes a recording in the Register under section 31A (3) of the
Real Property Act 1900
in relation to the resumption.

The Registrar-General must make the recordings in the Register and create the folios the Registrar-General considers necessary or appropriate to give effect to the order made under section 115, 131 or 136 in relation to the resumed land and the strata scheme.

heading.b: Variation or termination of strata schemes

block.txt: In this Part—

court
means the Supreme Court.

section 115 termination application
means an application made under section 115 that, under section 115 (6) or under sections 115 (6) and 133, is treated as an application for an order under section 136.

section 115 variation application
means an application made under section 115 that, under section 115 (6) or under sections 115 (6) and 140, is treated as an application for an order under section 131.

termination order
—
for Division 3—see section 136 (1), or
for Division 4—see section 143 (1) (a).

variation order
—see section 131 (1).

heading.b: Application for order consequent on damage to or destruction of building

block.txt: If a building the subject of a strata scheme is damaged or destroyed, any of the following persons may apply to the court for a variation order for the scheme—
an owner of a lot in the scheme,
a registered mortgagee or covenant chargee of a lot in the scheme,
if the scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor of the scheme,
the owners corporation.
Notice of the application must be served, in accordance with rules of court, on—
each person referred to in subsection (1), other than the applicant, and
the local council, and
the Registrar-General, and
any other person directed by the court.
The applicant and each person entitled to be served with notice of the application may appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.
A variation order may include directions about any of the following—
the substitution for the existing schedule of unit entitlement of a new schedule of unit entitlement,
the reinstatement in whole or in part of the building or, in the case of a part strata parcel, of the part of the building subject to the scheme,
the amendment of any strata development contract or strata management statement that relates to the parcel,
the transfer to or vesting in the owners corporation, free from mortgages, charges, covenant charges and writs, of the interests of owners of lots that have been wholly or partly destroyed,
the application of insurance amounts received by the owners corporation in relation to the damage to or destruction of the building,
the payment of amounts to or by the owners corporation, an owner of a lot or a lessor of a leasehold strata scheme,
if the order is made on a section 115 variation application—any matter referred to in section 115 (4),
if the application for the order is authorised by section 120—any matter referred to in section 115 (4) (a), (b) or (e),
any matter in relation to which the court considers it just and equitable, in the circumstances of the case, to make provision in the order.
A variation order has effect according to its tenor.
The court may, from time to time, change a variation order on the application of any person entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application for the order.
A variation order takes effect—
if the order is made on a section 115 variation application or an application authorised by section 120—on the day on which the resumption referred to in the order takes effect, or
otherwise—on the day specified in the order.

heading.b: Direction of court to treat application differently

block.txt: If the court considers that a variation order should not be made, it may, on application made by any person entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application for the order or on its own initiative, direct that the application be treated as an application for an order under section 136.
If the court makes a direction under subsection (1)—
the application the subject of the direction is taken to be made under section 135 by a person entitled to make the application, and
the applicant for the variation order, and any other person entitled to appear and be heard under that section, is entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the costs of proceedings under this Division on a section 115 variation application are payable by the resuming authority.

heading.b: Termination of strata schemes by order of court
Application for order to terminate strata scheme

block.txt: Any of the following persons may apply to the court for a termination order for a strata scheme—
an owner of a lot in the scheme,
a mortgagee or covenant chargee of a lot in the scheme,
if the scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor of the scheme,
the owners corporation.
Notice of the application must be served, in accordance with rules of court, on—
each person referred to in subsection (1), other than the applicant, and
the local council, and
the Registrar-General, and
any other person (including creditors of the owners corporation) directed by the court.
The applicant and each person entitled to be served with notice of the application may appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.

An application under subsection (1) (b) may be made by a prescribed authority having the benefit of a positive covenant only if the authority has applied under section 88I of the
Conveyancing Act 1919
for an order that the land the subject of the strata scheme be transferred to the authority.

In subsection (4),
prescribed authority
means a prescribed authority within the meaning of section 88D or 88E of the
Conveyancing Act 1919
.
A termination order may include directions about any of the following—
the sale or disposition of property of the owners corporation,
the discharge of the liabilities of the owners corporation,
the termination of any development scheme that relates to the parcel and the cancellation of the strata development contract,
the termination or amendment of a strata management statement that relates to the parcel,
the persons liable to contribute amounts required for the discharge of the liabilities of the owners corporation and the proportionate liability of the persons,
the distribution of the assets of the owners corporation and the proportionate entitlement of each person under the distribution,
the administration, powers, authorities, duties and functions of the owners corporation,
the voting power at meetings of the owners corporation of persons referred to in paragraph (e) or (f),
the winding up of the owners corporation, including the appointment, powers, authorities, duties and functions of any person to carry out the winding up,
any matter in relation to which the court considers it just and equitable, in the circumstances of the case, to make provision in the order.
The court may, from time to time, change a termination order on the application of any person entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application for the order.
A termination order takes effect—
if the order is made on a section 115 termination application or an application authorised by section 120—on the day on which the resumption referred to in the order takes effect, or
otherwise—on the day specified in the order.
When a termination order takes effect—

the estate or interest of the former owners in the part of the former parcel that consisted of common property vested in the owners corporation as agent for the former owners vests in the owners corporation as principal, subject only to an estate or interest recorded in—
the folio, or on any registered lease or registered sublease, evidencing the estate or interest of the owners corporation in the common property, or
the relevant folio created under section 29 (1), and

the estate or interest of each person in the part of the former parcel that did not consist of common property vests in the owners corporation as principal, subject only to an estate or interest recorded in—
the folio evidencing the estate or interest of the owners corporation in the common property comprised in the former parcel, or
the relevant folio created under section 29 (1),
to the extent the recorded estate or interest was capable of affecting a former lot, and
each person who, immediately before the order took effect, was an owner of a lot in the strata scheme ceases to be an owner of a lot in the scheme, and
each person whose estate or interest is divested by paragraph (b) has instead the rights and liabilities conferred or imposed on the person by the order, and

if the strata scheme is a leasehold strata scheme and the leases or another agreement provide for the payment of compensation for the value of improvements comprised in the parcel—the former lessor under the scheme is liable to pay compensation to each former owner for the value of the improvements comprised in the former parcel that is attributable to the lot leased by the former owner.
Compensation payable under subsection (1) (e) is to be determined in accordance with the formula set out in Schedule 6 or as otherwise agreed by the former lessor and former owner.
A termination order has effect according to its tenor and despite any provision of this Act, other than this Division.

heading.b: Dealing with disputes about value of improvements for leasehold strata schemes

block.txt: If, in relation to a former lot in a leasehold strata scheme that is terminated by a termination order, there is a dispute about the amount of compensation to be paid for the value of improvements attributable to the lot, the dispute must be resolved—

if provided for under the lease of the lot or the parties to the dispute otherwise agree—by arbitration under the
Commercial Arbitration Act 2010
, or
otherwise—by order of the court.
An application for an order of the court may be made by any party to the dispute.
Notice of the application must be served, in accordance with rules of court, on the persons directed by the court.
As far as practicable, all applications relating to the same leasehold strata scheme must be heard together.

heading.b: Direction of court to treat application differently

block.txt: If the court considers that a termination order should not be made, it may, on application made by any person entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application for the order or on its own initiative, direct that the application be treated as an application for a variation order.
If the court makes a direction under subsection (1)—
the application the subject of the direction is taken to be made under section 130 by a person entitled to make the application, and
the applicant for the termination order, and any other person entitled to appear and be heard under that section, is entitled to appear and be heard on the hearing of the application.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the costs of proceedings under this Division in relation to the following applications are payable by the resuming authority—
a section 115 termination application,
an application made under section 135 in relation to a proposed resumption of all the lots and all the common property in a strata scheme.

heading.b: Termination of strata schemes by Registrar-General
Application to Registrar-General for termination of strata scheme

block.txt: A person may apply to the Registrar-General for termination of a strata scheme, unless the scheme relates to a parcel that is subject to a strata development contract.
A person who proposes to make an application under this section must give public notice of the following—
details of the strata scheme that is proposed to be terminated,
a statement of intention to make the application.
The notice must be given—
at least 14 days, but not more than 6 months, before the application is made, and
in a way the Registrar-General considers appropriate to ensure notice of the application comes to the attention of the public.
Public notice is not required if the Registrar-General agrees it is not required.
Unless the Registrar-General otherwise agrees, the application must be signed by all of the following—
each owner of a lot in the scheme,
if the scheme is a leasehold strata scheme—the lessor of the scheme,
each registered lessee of a lot in the scheme,
each registered mortgagee, chargee and covenant chargee of a lot or of a registered lease of a lot or of the common property, if any, in the scheme.
Also, the application must be signed by the planning authority, if any, for subdivision of the land to which it relates.
The application must be accompanied by—
any documents, consents and evidence the Registrar-General requires, and

if required by the Registrar-General, a plan for the parcel acceptable for registration as a deposited plan and signed or consented to as required by Division 3 of Part 23 of the
Conveyancing Act 1919
.
On receiving an application to terminate a strata scheme, the Registrar-General may—
refuse to terminate the scheme.
A refusal by the Registrar-General to terminate a strata scheme does not prevent an application being made under section 135 for termination of the scheme.
A termination order takes effect when it is recorded by the Registrar-General in the folio for the land comprising the parcel.

heading.b: Registrar-General to record termination of strata scheme

block.txt: On recording a termination order, the Registrar-General must—
cancel the folios for the lots and common property in the former parcel, and
if the strata scheme is a freehold strata scheme—create a folio or folios for the land in the former parcel.

heading.b: Effect of order for freehold strata scheme

block.txt: When a termination order relating to a freehold strata scheme takes effect—
the owners corporation is dissolved and the strata scheme is terminated, and

the land in the former parcel immediately before the scheme was terminated and the assets of the former owners corporation vest in the former owners as tenants in common in shares proportional to the unit entitlements of their former lots (or in the former owners or in the other proportions set out in the application), and

the estate or interest of the former owners in land vested by this section is subject to any estate or interest registered or recorded, immediately before termination of the scheme, in the folios for the lots and the common property in the former parcel, and
the former owners of lots are liable for the liabilities of the owners corporation in shares proportional to the unit entitlements of their former lots, and
any legal proceedings begun by or against the owners corporation may be completed by or against the former owners.

heading.b: Effect of order for leasehold strata scheme

block.txt: When a termination order relating to a leasehold strata scheme takes effect—
the owners corporation is dissolved and the strata scheme is terminated, and
the former leases of each former lot and the former lease of the common property are determined, and
the persons who, immediately before the order took effect, were owners or lessees of the lots in the scheme cease to be owners or lessees of the lots, and
the former owners of the lots are liable for the liabilities of the owners corporation in shares proportional to the unit entitlements of their former lots, and
any legal proceedings begun by or against the owners corporation may be completed by or against the former owners, and

the assets of the former owners corporation immediately before the order took effect vest in the former lessor of the scheme or, if the application so provides, in the former owners as tenants in common in shares proportional to the unit entitlements of their former lots (or in the former owners or in the other proportions set out in the application), and

the land that comprises the former parcel is vested in the former lessor of the scheme freed and discharged from any mortgage or charge registered, immediately before termination of the scheme, in the folio for a lease of a lot or the common property in the former scheme.

heading.b: Termination of leasehold strata schemes on expiry of leases

block.txt:
When all leases of the lots and common property in a leasehold strata scheme expire or are otherwise determined without being wholly or partly replaced by further leases of the lots or common property registered under the
Real Property Act 1900
—
the scheme is terminated, and
the owners corporation is dissolved, and

if the leases or another agreement provide for the payment of compensation for the value of improvements comprised in the parcel—the former lessor of the scheme is liable to pay compensation to each former owner for the value of the improvements that is attributable to the former owner’s lot, and
all rights vested in the owners corporation immediately before its dissolution that, but for the dissolution, would have survived the expiry of the leases are vested in the former owners, and
